awd_titl_txt: Solving the Coarse Dust Conundrum: What Processes Cause Large-scale Models to Underestimate Coarse Dust Transport?
awd_abstract_narration:
At any given time, our atmosphere contains tens of millions of metric tons of desert dust. This dust seeds clouds and scatters and absorbs sunlight and, when it settles from our atmosphere, fertilizes ecosystems and darkens snow and ice. Basic physics predicts that coarse dust particles - still no larger than the thickness of a human hair - quickly settle out of the atmosphere. However, measurements indicate that this is not the case; instead, coarse dust can remain in the atmosphere for days and travel thousands of kilometers from its source. This dust therefore has more time to impact the Earth and its weather and climate. This makes it critical to determine the processes that cause dust to stay in the atmosphere longer than expected, and account for these missing processes in climate and weather models.

This project uses Large Eddy Simulations (LES) and other techniques to test three hypotheses of the nature of the process(es) that help keep coarse dust aloft. Specifically, this project tests whether dust asphericity, electrification, and / or turbulence in dusty layers keep dust aloft against the action of gravitational settling. The project will result in a parameterization of dust gravitational settling that includes these missing processes and that can be used in weather and climate models. This will allow these models to more accurately represent desert dust in the atmosphere and its impact on the Earth system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
At any given time, our atmosphere contains tens of millions of metric tons of desert dust. This dust seeds clouds and scatters and absorbs sunlight and, when it settles from our atmosphere, fertilizes ecosystems and darkens snow and ice. Basic physics predicts that coarse dust particles - still no larger than the thickness of a human hair - quickly settle out of the atmosphere. However, measurements show that this is not the case; instead, coarse dust can remain in the atmosphere for days and travel thousands of kilometers from its source. This dust therefore has more time to impact the Earth and its weather and climate. This makes it critical to determine the processes that cause dust to stay in the atmosphere longer than expected, and account for these missing processes in climate and weather models. The aim of this project was to do just that. 

 

This grant's contributions to intellectual merit included the following:

  • Discovering that coarse desert dust accounts for approximately a third of all particulate matter by mass, yet that current climate models miss approximately three quarters of this coarse dust.

  • Discovering that current equations greatly underestimate the emission of coarse desert dust, which contributes to the underestimation of these particles by climate and weather models. However, even after correcting these models, they still underestimate coarse dust, showing that models also remove these particles too quickly from models.

  • Discovering that coarse dust is much more aspherical than climate and weather models account for, which keeps these particles aloft for longer by increasing their air resistance, and which partially explains the unexpectedly long atmospheric lifetime of coarse desert dust.

  • Discovering that coarse dust is likely less absorbing of solar radiation than current climate models assume.

  • Discovering that portions of the upper atmosphere are actually in the regime of stratified turbulence, and that this turbulence can greatly impact the time dust particles remain suspended in the atmosphere and the distance that they can travel.

  • Discovering that coarse dust emitted over the Saharan desert can reach America because of the turbulence in the Saharan Air Layer

  • Developed a new simple model for turbulence that can help mitigate existing issues of underpredicting dust transport in climate models.

  • Funding from this grant contributed to the publication of over 20 scientific articles in premier scientific journals.

 

This grant's contributions to broader impacts included the following:

  • The training of scientists from various backgrounds, including six undergraduates (five female and two from underrepresented minorities); three graduate students who went on to prestigious postdoctoral fellowship positions; and a postdoctoral scholar, who went on to a faculty position.

  • Various improvements of the representation of (coarse) dust in climate models, including for the Community Earth System Model, a state-of-the-art open-source climate model that contributes to climate assessments by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and other national and international organizations. These improvements include developing and implementing into CESM a more process-based dust emission module that improves agreement about various observations, a simple parameterization for the settling speed of aspherical dust that is now used by various climate models, and the development of a parameterization for coarse dust emission.

  • Development of a (coarse) dust emission dataset spanning pre-industrial to modern times (1841-2000) that is used by the World Climate Research Programme’s (WCRP) Aerosols and Chemistry Model Intercomparison Project (AerChemMIP) and possibly other Model Intercomparison Projects that inform the IPCC assessment reports.
